title: Why Your Reels Have 50 Views (And How to Fix It)
excerpt: Frustrated that your Instagram Reels only get 50 views? We reveal 5 reasons why Reels lack reach and advise how to change it.
content:
Why do my Reels have no reach?

If you invest time in creating Instagram Reels but the result is only 50 views and no new clients, you are not alone. Many business profiles face the same problem. Here is how to fix it.

1. Weak Intro and Zero Engagement

Symptom: Most people turn off your video within a few seconds.

Diagnosis: The first few seconds are critical. If you don't start with a hook, the algorithm stops offering it. A weak intro – like a long company logo – causes viewers to scroll away.

Cure: Focus on the first 2–3 seconds. Start with something surprising or visually attractive. Instead of a static logo, show the final result immediately.

2. Recycled Content or “Reels Routine”

Symptom: Your videos look the same. You use the same template or recycle TikTok videos with a watermark.

Cure: Innovate format and content. Alternate styles: speak to the camera one time, make a photo collage next. It is also important to remove any TikTok watermarks.

3. Bad Timing and Zero Interaction

Symptom: The video looks great, but you posted it when your audience is offline. Plus, you don't reply to comments.

Cure: Focus on timing and community management. Ideally, publish when your fans are online.

4. Too Salesy Without Value

Symptom: Every video is an ad – “buy this”. Viewers get nothing but an offer.

Cure: Try to give value or emotion in every video. Instead of a “product report”, show a tip, trick, guide, or customer story. The 80/20 rule works great.

5. You Don't Know Your Audience

Symptom: You create generic videos that aim “nowhere”.

Cure: Clarify who you want to reach and adapt the content to them, not yourself. Imagine one ideal follower and “tell” the Reel to them.

title: How Much Does Video Production Actually Cost in 2026?
excerpt: Video production prices can vary from a few hundred to thousands. See a transparent breakdown of how much it REALLY costs to shoot Reels, corporate videos, or TV spots.
content:
Do you know how much a video costs?

You may have heard the answer: “It depends…”. Yes, the budget depends on many factors. But today we will get specific.

Short Social Video (Reels, Promo Clip)

Price: If you create it in-house, direct costs can be zero. For external production, low-budget Reels cost hundreds. For full-service, expect more.

What's included: Cameraman/editor work and basic production. Short shoot, basic edit, color grading.

Corporate Video (Presentation, Case Study)

Price: This ranges from mid-hundreds to thousands. Lower end gives you a simple one-day shoot. Higher end brings more shooting days and advanced graphics.

What's included: Complete service: pre-production (script), production (crew, lights) and post-production (edit, grading, music, voiceover).

TV Spot (Commercial)

Price: Professional TV commercials cost tens of thousands. The upper limit practically doesn't exist.

What's included: Everything: creative concept, director, large crew, actors, locations, make-up, costumes, special effects, licensed music.

What Influences the Price?

  • Length: Longer video = more work.
  • Shooting Days & Locations: More days = higher costs.
  • Crew Size: More experts = higher quality and price.
  • Actors: Fees and casting cost money.
  • Post-production: Animation and 3D effects are expensive.

title: I Shot 500+ Reels. Here Are 5 Things Nobody Tells You
excerpt: How to shoot Reels that really work? After 500+ videos for companies, I have some brutally honest insights. I reveal 5 things nobody tells you.
content:
Truth #1: Most Reels Won't Succeed (And That's OK)

Nobody says this aloud – you mostly see successes. But reality? The vast majority of Reels end up average. Not every video goes viral.

Truth #2: One Viral Hit Won't Save You, Consistency Will

I used to believe one viral video was enough. Mistake. A viral hit is a nice ego boost, but often short-lived.

Truth #3: Trends Won't Save You – Content Must Fit You

A trend is not a strategy. If I sell accounting services, a TikTok dance won't bring clients. Authenticity is worth more.

Truth #4: Reels Don't Sell By Themselves

Reels are great for attention – but they won't sell for you without a follow-up process. Give a clear CTA: “Click the link in bio”.

Truth #5: Success = Lots of Trial and Error

Nobody has a 100% recipe for success. Even after 500 videos, I can't say “I know everything”. Creating Reels is constant experimentation.

Conclusion: Go all in, but with open eyes. If you need a helping hand with Reels, get in touch.

title: 5 Mistakes Killing Your Reels Reach (And How to Fix Them)
excerpt: Why is nobody watching your videos? You might be making one of these beginner mistakes. Read how to give Instagram algorithms exactly what they want.
content:
1. The First 3 Seconds Decide

People don't have time. If you don't grab them immediately, they scroll past. Forget long logos and intros. Get straight to the point.

2. Bad Lighting

You don't need a hundred-thousand-dollar camera, but you need light. Daylight from a window is free and looks great.

3. Missing Captions

Up to 40% of people watch videos without sound. If you don't have captions, you lose half your audience.

4. No Call to Action (CTA)

What should people do after watching? Tell them. 'Follow for more tips', 'Click the link in bio'.

5. Boring

Entertain, educate, inspire. If the video brings no value, the algorithm will bury it.

title: Why Your Facebook Ads Aren't Working (Viewer Psychology)
excerpt: Spending needed on PPC but no sales? The problem isn't the ad settings, but the creative. Find out how to engage.
content:
People Hate Ads

Nobody goes on Facebook to watch ads. People want to be entertained or see what friends are doing.

The 'Native Content' Rule

Your ad must not look like an ad. It must look like TikTok, like a Vlog, like entertainment. This is called UGC (User Generated Content) style.

Emotions Sell

A boring list of product parameters interests no one. Show how the person will FEEL when they use the product. Show the problem and its solution.
